title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [25–27?] april 1869
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [25–27?] April 1869
text: (about 20)April 1869 My dear Walti got you to daytoday with the envelovesenvelopes and money all safe and sound waltWalt what made you think that was maryMarysMary's georgeGeorge i knew when i first saw it that it wasentwasn't him he is not on the road he lives to meridan near springfieldSpringfield this young man that was killed was buried at JamacaJamaica there has been a full account of it in the eagle the Dr pray and his mother that was killed the mother was old judge dikemansDikeman's daughter and the rushmoresRushmore's wife is sister to mrsMrs. pray likewise dikemansDikeman's daughter she was not on the car it was the northportNorthport train Charlick the manager or owawer it was awful to read) well waltWalt last saturdaySaturday i had one of heydsHeyde's awful letters if possible the worst one yet over two sheets of paper dontdon't you think i had a good time reading it) well i got his in the forenoon and i got one from han in the afternafternoon if i hadenthadn't got hers i should have felt very bad i will sent the letter to you the next time i write i want georgeGeorge to read it before i send it i wontwon't tell any thing she writes i dontdon't mean to send mrMr. Heydes although he mentions your name not the most polite you have ever had it mentioned i wrote han a letter right away that we should expect her as soon as we got a little settled i hope he wontwon't keep it as he did yours) i had a letter from matt they have got a house and the two girls to work matt says if she was only rid of her coughfcough she should be real happy she said she would have sent me some change but they were dead broke i dontdon't think its much use to get a high salary)walt this is great writinwriting but i have had to work so hard that my hands is so trembly and stiff i cantcan't write maybeemaybe you can make it out the germanGerman woman that i expected to have to help me about moving has took it on her head to get married about the 1 of may so i had to doodo more than i could hardly get along with georgeGeorge is to camdenCamden but will come home wensdayWednesday or thursdayThursday night the house aintain't done but we shall have to move on saturdaySaturday your next letter you must direct portland avePortland Ave.) i beleivebelieve the number is 71 opposite the Arsenal at any rate our old letter man has that route i think mrsMrs. steers is very clever does all she can to accomadateaccommodate but the people is coming in thursdayThursday evening i have given up the parlor and all i can but the only comfort i have that i shant have to move again very soon any how but strange things happen in these days dontdon't they Walt so its best not to make any calcalationcalculation good bie walterWalter my love as usual to the OconorsO'ConnorsLWthis compliment georgeGeorge cut out of the philadelphaPhiladelphia bulletin Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [25–27?] April 1869
